    Content from The Scholarly Publishing Process

    Last updated on 2025-04-30 | Edit this page

    Estimated time: 75 minutes

    Overview

    Questions

    • What does it mean to publish research?
    • How do institutional, funder, and publisher policies affect authoring choices?
    • How can open science values reshape scholarly publishing?

    Objectives

    • Explain how to get an article published in a traditional scholarly publication.
    • Locate publications that have integrated open science processes into their publishing workflow.
    • Discuss how open science values can affect the collaboration process of writing a scholarly article.

    Narrative Setup

    An open–science–minded author is told their performance review depends on publishing in a peer-reviewed journal. They want to use GitHub to collaborate with coauthors transparently. This episode explores how the scholarly publishing process works and how open science values can be integrated.

    Overview of Scholarly Publishing

    Researchers often face the “publish or perish” mandate. But what qualifies as “publishing”? And who decides what’s acceptable?

    Three stakeholder groups shape this: 1. Academic institutions (e.g., employers, tenure committees) 2. Funders (e.g., federal agencies) 3. Publishers (e.g., commercial or scholarly presses)

    - The Rise of Open Access - arXiv - Peer Review

    OPTIONAL Exercise: Jargon Busting

    Adapted from Library Carpentry: Have learners identify and explain publishing-related jargon in groups, then share out.

    Case Studies

    Case Study 1: Conflicting Policies

    Dr. Jay publishes in a hybrid journal that delays repository access beyond their funder’s requirements. They must renegotiate or change journals.

    Case Study 2: Aligned Incentives

    Dr. Ripken publishes in a fully open platform supported by institutional partnerships and funder mandates.

    Case Study 3: No Open Science Incentives

    Dr. Brown chooses a closed journal based on personal networks and convenience, without considering long-term openness or access.

    Discussion Exercise

    • What could Dr. Jay have done differently at the project planning stage?
    • If Dr. Ripken’s journal fees were too high, what would be their next step?
    • Should Dr. Brown’s team explore more open options?

    Choosing a Publication Venue

    • Use Think. Check. Submit. to assess journal credibility
    • Check funder and institutional policies
    • Evaluate a journal’s open science stance beyond JIFs

    Publishing Workflows

    Traditional Workflow
    Researchers → Peer Review → Edits → Publication → Library Access

    Open Science Workflow
    Researchers → Preprints → Community Feedback → Submission → Open Peer Review → Open Access Publication

    Exercise: Quiz – Traditional vs. Open Science Publishing

    (T/F statements provided in source doc)

    Exercise: Journal Evaluation

    Groups evaluate journals for openness using: - Code4Lib Journal - Practical Academic Librarianship - International Journal on Digital Libraries

    Key Points

    • Understand the institutional, funder, and publisher influences on publishing choices
    • Assess publication venues critically for openness and accessibility
    • Open science values can be embedded in authoring, publishing, and reviewing choices

    Content from Open Authoring Tools

    Last updated on 2025-04-30 | Edit this page

    Estimated time: 50 minutes

    Overview

    Questions

    • What open authoring tools are available for writing scholarly articles?
    • How can I create manuscripts using Markdown, LaTeX, or RMarkdown?
    • How can open documents be converted to publisher-required formats like DOCX or PDF?

    Objectives

    • Describe collaborative, open authoring tools that can be used to write scholarly articles.
    • Locate templates in Markdown and LaTeX that can be used to write a scholarly article.
    • Understand what tools can convert open document formats to proprietary ones required by scholarly publications.

    Key Points

    • Authors can use open source tools to write and produce manuscript submissions.
    • The open science community continues to develop workflows for submitting manuscripts to publishers that require proprietary formats.
    • Some journals do accept open source file formats during the initial submission or review stage.

    Overview

    There are many collaborative authoring tools available today. DOC, DOCX, and PDF are the formats most commonly requested by scholarly publishers. Unfortunately, these formats are not open source. So how do we align our open science values with these constraints?

    By using alternative, open authoring tools.

    AlternativeTo is a useful resource for discovering open-source or privacy-respecting alternatives to common proprietary tools.

    WYSIWYG Tools

    If you prefer a What-You-See-Is-What-You-Get (WYSIWYG) editor, here are some common options:

    • Google Docs: free but not open source.
    • LibreOffice: free and open source — feature comparison with Microsoft Office
    • Apache OpenOffice: free and open source, though not regularly updated.

    These tools support DOCX files and include features like collaboration and version history. However, they do not easily create semantically structured, machine-readable documents — a key goal for FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) outputs.

    WYSIWYM Tools

    For semantic authoring, consider What-You-See-Is-What-You-Mean (WYSIWYM) formats such as:

    Markdown

    Markdown is a plain text format with lightweight semantic markup.

    You can write Markdown in any text editor and save the file with a .md extension. A good place to get started is:

    • CommonMark Tutorial (10 minutes)

    Markdown Resources

    • PoisotLab manuscript template
    • Markdown for Manuscripts
    • Sustainable authorship with Pandoc
    • The Carpentries Markdown lesson

    RMarkdown

    RMarkdown combines Markdown with embedded R code to create reproducible research documents. It supports output to PDF, Word, and HTML.

    • RMarkdown in Data Carpentry
    • Reproducible submission to JMSACL

    LaTeX

    LaTeX is a document preparation system using plain text and markup for structure and formatting. You write .tex files and compile them into PDF.

    Start learning LaTeX:

    • LaTeX: Document Structure Exercise
    • LaTeX Novice Typesetting (Carpentries Incubator)
    • LaTeX Course (Parts 1 & 2)

    Meeting Publisher Requirements

    If publishers only accept proprietary formats, how can you still use open tools?

    1. Most WYSIWYG editors allow export to DOCX or PDF.

      • Caveat: These may not be digitally accessible or semantically rich.

    2. Tools like Pandoc can convert Markdown, LaTeX, and other open formats into publisher-accepted ones.

    3. Some publishers accept open formats:

      • LaTeX: Commonly accepted at submission or for typesetting post-acceptance.
      • Markdown: Some open publishing platforms accept markdown submissions.

    Examples

    • Authorea
    • PubPub
    • Overleaf
    • Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS)
    • Programming Historian Guidelines

    Exercise: Markdown Basics

    Complete the CommonMark tutorial. Try creating headings, lists, links, and formatting text using a plain text editor.

    Exercise: LaTeX Document Structure

    Work through the LaTeX structure lesson to get familiar with sections, document classes, and compiling.

    Content from Open Peer Review

    Last updated on 2025-04-30 | Edit this page

    Estimated time: 40 minutes

    Overview

    Questions

    • What is open peer review?
    • What are the benefits and challenges of open peer review?
    • How can I respond to critiques of open peer review?

    Introduction

    Open Peer Review (OPR) reflects Open Science principles such as transparency, collegiality, and inclusivity. In OPR, reviewers’ names and/or their reports are made public. Sometimes, articles allow reader comments post-publication.

    TODO

    Insert figure: Timeline of OPR Evolution

    A Brief History of Open Peer Review

    While modern peer review became formalized in the 20th century, signed and public reviews date back to Enlightenment-era scholarly correspondence. The Journal of Medical Internet Research introduced OPR in 1999, and since then, practices have diversified.

    For background, see:

    • Wikipedia
    • Nature Editorial (DOI:10.1038/6295)
    • F1000Research (DOI:10.12688/f1000research.11369.2)

    Types of Open Peer Review

    Type Who Is It Open To? What Happens?
    Open Identities Reviewers and Authors Reviewer names are known to authors or publicly listed.
    Open Reports Reviewers, Authors, Public Reports are published with the article, authors may or may not accept all suggestions.
    Open Participation Everyone The public can review and annotate articles, post-publication.

    TODO

    Insert figure: Visual spectrum of open peer review types

    Challenge: True or False?

    Indicate whether each statement is true or false.

    1. Peer review exists on a spectrum from closed to open.
    2. Open Participation means no pre-publication review occurred.
    3. Open Reports mean authors must incorporate all feedback.

    Solutions

    1. ✅ True – Peer review practices vary.
    2. ❌ False – Open Participation allows comments post-publication but doesn’t exclude pre-publication review.
    3. ❌ False – Open Reports only require that feedback is published, not implemented.

    Benefits of Open Review

    • Transparency: Encourages civility and collegiality.
    • Recognition: Signed reviews can be cited, valued in hiring or promotion.
    • Inclusion: Allows early-career or interdisciplinary scholars to participate.

    TODO

    Insert infographic: Benefits of Open Peer Review

    Common Arguments Against Open Review

    Concern Response
    Signed reviews deter participation Early resistance has faded as norms change.
    Bias in reviewing known authors May introduce bias; mitigated with optional anonymity.
    Editors already serve this function Editors retain final decision authority regardless of review format.

    “Editors take responsibility for decisions and the advice informing them.” – Nature Editorial

    Ethical Considerations

    • Power dynamics: Seniority, gender, institutional prestige.
    • Peer pressure: Fear of backlash when reviews are public.

    TODO: Insert figure – Sidebar on ethical issues in open review

    Toward Equitable Review

    Rather than aiming for maximum openness, aim for equitable peer review:

    • Keep author anonymity optional.
    • Let reviewers choose whether to sign.
    • Encourage transparent reports and public comments.
    • Adapt practices to context, reducing harm from bias or power imbalance.

    See: Indiana Libraries Peer Review Guide

    TODO

    Insert diagram: Open vs. Equitable Review Approaches

    Challenge: Positionality Reflection

    Based on your own background (e.g., gender, seniority, race), how might open review benefit or hinder your ability to publish? Reflect privately or share with a partner.

    Key Points

    • Peer review practices vary along a spectrum of openness.
    • Open peer review can support inclusivity but must be thoughtfully implemented.
    • Culture change is key to lasting improvements in peer review.
    • Equity, not just transparency, should guide review system design.
